title: How to Shoot for Focus Stacking

steps.headline: Be sure to have a tripod.
steps.description: You can do it handheld, but there won't be nearly the precision that you want. Alternatively, you can use a focusing rail or something like a Gorillapod with 'socks' on its 'feet'.

steps.headline: Be sure the subject is very stable.
steps.description: It is next to impossible to shoot macro, let alone use a focusing rail if the subject is moving around.

steps.headline: Have a source of light.
steps.description: As with all macro photography, you need a strong light.

steps.headline: Set up your macro shot.
steps.description: It is best to have a certain order of focus. Front to back or back to front.

steps.headline: Determine how much/how many shots you want to take and the area of focus.
Focus where you will start the stack at.
steps.description: For the purposes of this article, the front. Take the photograph.

steps.headline: Move slightly past the first point of focus.
Take another shot just a little further back.
steps.description: Take the photograph. Obviously, this will differ greatly from snapping a panorama type image to a macro image.

steps.headline: Continue until you have all of the images that you need.
Offload them off to the computer and open the program that you will use to stack them in.

text:
Be sure to have a tripod. You can do it handheld, but there won't be nearly the precision that you want. Alternatively, you can use a focusing rail or something like a Gorillapod with 'socks' on its 'feet'. Be sure the subject is very stable. It is next to impossible to shoot macro, let alone use a focusing rail if the subject is moving around. Have a source of light. As with all macro photography, you need a strong light. Set up your macro shot. It is best to have a certain order of focus. Front to back or back to front. Determine how much/how many shots you want to take and the area of focus.  Focus where you will start the stack at. For the purposes of this article, the front. Take the photograph. Move slightly past the first point of focus. Take the photograph. Take another shot just a little further back. Take the photograph. Obviously, this will differ greatly from snapping a panorama type image to a macro image. Continue until you have all of the images that you need.  Offload them off to the computer and open the program that you will use to stack them in. Some are:
Adobe Photoshop (Commercial)
Photoshop CS
